cmCourseInfo.description: This course focuses on the scientific principles underlying current controversial issues in the health sciences. The four six-week modules will explore contemporary topics such as stem cells, transplantation, regenerative medicine, vaccination, and personalized medicine from the perspective of developing opinion based on scientific understanding. Not eligible for CR/NCR.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Issues in Health Science
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, SMC One,UC One, Vic One, Woodsworth One

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: Scientific discoveries shape how we see ourselves and decisions made about how we live our lives and run our societies. We will discuss broader implications of research findings for making social decisions. Topics will include: genes and genetic determinism; evolutionary explanations of behavior and disease; scientific uncertainty and public communication. Not eligible for CR/NCR.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science and Social Choice
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, SMC One, UC One, Vic One, Woodsworth One

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Canadian Health Policy in the Global Context

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores public health policy in Canada and connects it to the global political context. We study the evolution of Canadian healthcare into its current form and then turn to international institutional arrangements that offer different approaches to a range of health policy challenges, including universal health care, antimicrobial drug resistance, infectious disease, non-communicable diseases, maternal newborn and child health and environmental health. Not eligible for CR/NCR.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Health Policy in the Global Context

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar examines the rise of nationalisms and nation states since the 16th century and the ways these intersect or compete with international movements, ideas and institutions. Topics may include the Enlightenment, the French Revolution, the birth of Germany, peace movements, the League of Nations, and humanitarian relief. Open only to students admitted to Trinity One. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: National versus International
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar course provides an orientation to the study of contemporary world order. Topics may include important legacies of the world wars of the 20th century, theories of conflict and cooperation, and new forms of transnational collaboration. Open only to students admitted to Trinity One. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Governance
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Public Policy and the Public Good

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 10, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: What is public policy? Is there such a thing as the public good? What is the purpose of government in a liberal democratic society? How should policy makers respond when competing goods (e.g., freedom and security) conflict with each other? Ethical issues underlying a selection of contemporary public policy issues. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Public Policy and the Public Good
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, SMC One, UC One, Vic One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: How do we know what kinds of public policy will work and what will not? How do we assess the effectiveness of a policy? An historical examination of ways in which Canadian governments have addressed a range of policy problems. Case studies of areas of federal and provincial activity today. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Making Public Policy Work
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, SMC One, UC One, Vic One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 4, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: A seminar course that explores ethical issues through the study of works of the creative imagination that pose or provoke questions of right and wrong, good and evil, justice and injustice. The selected works will be drawn from such fields as literature, film, and the visual and performing arts. Open only to students admitted to Trinity One. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethics and the Creative Imagination
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: A seminar course that explores ethical issues arising in such public domains as international relations, law, science, business, the arts, civil society, public life, the mass media, popular culture. Issues may include war crimes, human rights, assisted suicide, genetic engineering, corporate responsibility, private vice and public virtue, the tragedy of the commons. Open only to students admitted to Trinity One. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethics and the Public Sphere
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Vic One, UC One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For “E” indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 10, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: What is the relationship between moral values and the law? What role does the law play in enabling people to live better lives? Are legal institutions and actors subject to higher ethical standards? In this course we will read texts from legal theory and political philosophy to try to explain the connection between ethics and the law. This will provide the basis for thinking about some historical and contemporary legal cases, as well as ethical issues judges, lawyers, and lawmakers face in their professional roles. Not eligible for CR/NCR.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethics and the Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For "E" indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to a number of critical approaches and develops the students own responses to texts through an understanding of critical vocabulary and the art of close analytical reading. Students also learn how to make their own critical analysis more effective through oral presentations and written work.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Reading and Critical Writing

cmCourseInfo.description: First term: students are taught how to recognize, analyze, evaluate, and construct arguments in ordinary English prose. Second term: one or more discipline-related modes of reasoning (e.g., scientific reasoning, ethical reasoning, legal reasoning) studied with reference to a selection of contemporary social issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modes of Reasoning (formerly TRN200H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Key texts from various disciplines that articulate fundamental features, limitations, and possibilities of contemporary society are introduced. Political consent, economics, governmental administration, the global / post-colonial world, historical transformation, gender politics, and media may be addressed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Society, its Limits and Possibilities

courses.name: Introduction to Law and Legal Reasoning

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: January 17, 2018

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: January 17, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to legal reasoning through progressively complex exercises. First, hypotheticals expose students to basic skills required for legal reasoning. Second, they analyze simplified versions of specially selected concrete cases. Third, the course analyses real cases discussed in first year courses in law school.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Law and Legal Reasoning

courses.name: The Art of Health Science Discovery

cmCourseInfo.description: Illustrated by contemporary examples, students go through the stages of the scientific discovery process. From initial idea, through literature review, funding (grant writing and assessment), experimental design and critical analysis of data through to the public dissemination of results by publication, the patent process and development of intellectual property.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Art of Health Science Discovery

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.content:

For "E" indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Health Policy in Canada: Past, Present and Future

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the nature and impact of public health policy in Canada. The course describes the origins of Canadian health policy, its evolution towards its current form and the choices resulting from aging populations and the increasing costs associated with a high standard of health care.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health Policy in Canada: Past, Present and Future

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
For "E" indicator courses: contact Kiran Sahota, Room 300, Larkin Building, Monday to Friday from 9:00am-12:00pm and 2:00-5:00pm, at 416-978-8454 or artsdean@trinity.utoronto.ca.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 21, 2017

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the nature and impact of policy relationships designed to improve global public health. We explore the analytical tools necessary to study these institutional arrangements and examine successes and failures of these policy relationships across a range of global health policy challenges including infectious disease and child health.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Politics of Global Health

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

courses.name: Ordering International Relations in the Age of Empire

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines the origins and development of three fundamental norms in international relations (sovereignty; free trade; human rights) in their historical, imperial context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ordering International Relations in the Age of Empire
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Admission to International Relations Major or Specialist program
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Prerequisite courses for entry into International Relations Major or Specialist Program

cmCourseInfo.description: The nature and justification of legal rules as preparation for the study of basic principles of law governing the relations between individual citizens, and the relations between individual citizens and the state. A selection of contract, tort, criminal and administrative law. Restricted to students in the major program Ethics, Society, and Law.
cmCourseInfo.title: Basic Principles of Law
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Active in ASMAJ1618 only if enrolling in the Fall/Winter session. A student must be in third or fourth year.

cmCourseInfo.description: Students who have engaged in a research project abroad participate in a regular forum in which they present their research projects and discuss their varied experiences of work and social engagement in different foreign environments. Students prepare a detailed scholarly article based on their research.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Ethics, Society, and Law

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines a set of selected topics in ethics, society, and law. The topics will be based on the research interests of an individual instructor. Both the topics and the instructor may change with each offering of the course, and the course is not expected to be offered every year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Selected Topics in Ethics, Society, and Law

courses.name: Comparative American, British and Canadian Foreign Policy

cmCourseInfo.description: The origins and evolution of American, British and Canadian foreign policy from the late 18th century to the present. Policies are compared in order to understand the development of these countries as nations and actors in the international community.
cmCourseInfo.title: Comparative American, British and Canadian Foreign Policy
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Students must have a background in one of Canadian, British or American history.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course aims to train senior-level science students in a wide range of writing genres, focusing on a diversity of non-scientific audiences and writing styles. In addition, students learn to read and analyze texts in order to understand rhetorical strategies and devices.
cmCourseInfo.title: Science Writing for Non-Scientific Audiences
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Students in science specialist or major programs. Permission by instructor.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Non-science students, first or second year students.
